title: Revising the Ukraine-U.S. Peace Plan Amid Concerns
summary: U.S. and Ukrainian officials are actively working to revise a peace plan aimed at ending the nearly four-year war in Ukraine. The original 28-point proposal faced bipartisan and international criticism for including demands perceived as favoring Russia, such as capping Ukraine's military size, abandoning NATO membership aspirations, and surrendering territory in Donetsk. In response, the plan has been reduced to 19 points after discussions led by figures like Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Ukrainian presidential chief of staff Andriy Yermak. The U.S. has acknowledged two major sticking points and, through meetings in Geneva and elsewhere, is listening to Ukrainian concerns. White House spokesperson Karoline Leavitt expressed optimism about the progress, highlighting efforts to narrow gaps and make the plan more acceptable to Ukraine. This revision process underscores the complexities of international diplomacy and the need for balanced agreements in conflict resolution.
